title: Question 124

children: A 75-year-old man with Graves disease is evaluated for fever, cough, and confusion. He did not refill his last prescription for methimazole.
Temperature is 39.4 °C (102.9 °F), blood pressure is 96/54 mm Hg, and pulse rate is 138/min. He is delirious. Pulmonary crackles are present.
Thyroid-stimulating hormone
level is <0.1 µU/mL (0.1 mU/L);
free thyroxine
level is 4.4 ng/dL (56.8 pmol/L). Chest radiograph shows a left lower lobe infiltrate.
Antibiotics for community-acquired pneumonia are initiated.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

Thyroid storm is distinguished from hyperthyroidism by the presence of severe and life-threatening symptoms, most often including cardiac dysfunction (tachyarrhythmias, shock, heart failure) and others (fever, delirium).

Therapy for thyroid storm includes a combination of β-blockers, antithyroidal medications, potassium iodide, hydrocortisone therapy, cooling of body temperature, and treatment of any underlying precipitant.
This patient should receive propranolol, propylthiouracil, and hydrocortisone (
Option C

). He has pneumonia complicated by thyroid storm, a life-threatening condition. Common precipitants of thyroid storm include iatrogenic causes, such as therapy with radioactive iodine, abrupt cessation of antithyroidal drugs, acute nonthyroidal illnesses, and thyroid or nonthyroid surgery in a patient with unrecognized or inadequately treated thyrotoxicosis. The diagnosis of thyroid storm is clinical. What distinguishes thyroid storm from hyperthyroidism is the presence of severe and life-threatening symptoms, most often including cardiac dysfunction (tachyarrhythmias, shock, heart failure) and others (fever, delirium). A point scale, such as the Burch-Wartofsky Point Scale, can be used to facilitate the early diagnosis of thyroid storm. There is no cutoff range of free thyroxine (T
) or free triiodothyronine (T

) levels that supports the diagnosis. Patients in thyroid storm require admission to an intensive care unit. Appropriate therapy includes a combination of β-blockers, antithyroidal medications, potassium iodide, hydrocortisone therapy, cooling of body temperature, and treatment of any underlying precipitant. Iodide should be administered more than 1 hour after antithyroid drugs to avoid providing substrate to the gland.
The combination of atenolol, methimazole and cholestyramine (
Option A
) is not the best therapy for thyroid storm. Propranolol and propylthiouracil have the added benefit over atenolol and methimazole in thyroid storm by reducing T
-to-T

conversion. Usually, high dosages of propranolol (240-480 mg/d) and propylthiouracil (>450 mg/d) are required to take advantage of that benefit and to adequately treat thyroid storm. Cholestyramine interrupts the enterohepatic recirculation of thyroid hormone, reducing total thyroid hormone burden. Cholestyramine may be used as adjunctive therapy or when the patient cannot take a thionamide such as propylthiouracil. Glucocorticoids are commonly recommended for thyroid storm because they decrease conversion of T
to T
, suppress stimulating antibody production, and simultaneously treat hypocortisolism, if present, and should be part of this patient's therapy.
Plasmapheresis (
Option B

) can remove cytokines, antibodies, and thyroid hormones from plasma. The evidence supporting plasmapheresis for thyroid storm is from case reports. Plasmapheresis is usually reserved for patients in whom standard therapy has failed.
Radioactive iodine ablation (
Option D

) may acutely exacerbate the thyrotoxic state by releasing preformed thyroid hormone from injured thyrocytes and takes many weeks (or even months) to bring about hypothyroidism. Therefore, this therapy is not appropriate for patients in thyroid storm.

references: Feldt-Rasmussen U, Emerson CH, Ross DS, et al. Thoughts on the Japanese and American perspectives on thyroid storm [Editorial]. Thyroid. 2019;29:1033-1035.
